_header: Woe worth your hearts so planted in pride
Note:
From Conuersion of Swerers (5289), occurring separately. For a single stanza rhyme royal with a very similar ‘Wo worth’ anaphora see 4497. Also compare Hawes’ Convercyon of Swerers, 2547 (see Berdan (1920)
XBerdan, John M. Early Tudor Poetry, 1485-1547. New York: Macmillan, 1920, 184, note 2); Court of Sapience (5365) stanza 67; and 6775.
_description: Curses and Blessings — eight stanzas rhyme royal with ‘Wo worth’ and ‘Blessyd be ye’ anaphora.

BLHar4294.First Lines:
Wo worth your hartis so plantyd in prydeWo worthe your wrath &
                    mortall envye…
BLHar4294.Last Lines:
…Blessyd be ye in the lyfe temperallWhich applye yourselfe to
                    Ioy celestyall
BLHar4294.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James. 
             “Inedited Pieces, No. IV.” 
             Notes and Queries
         4th ser. 3 (1869): 8-9: 9.
